stk.molecular.topologies.cof module¶

Defines COF topologies.

How the assembly process works for 2D COF topologies.¶

Linker topologies.¶

Linker topologies are those which use a building block with two functional groups and a building block with three or more functional groups. These are implemented as subclasses to LinkerCOFLattice.

As for any assembly process, there are 2 main stages: placement of building blocks and yielding of functional groups which react.

A 2D COF topology can be defined through vertices and the edges which connect them. The building block with 3 or more functional groups sits on the vertices while the building block with 2 functional groups sits on the edges. To assemble a COF topology, first the vertices and edges are defined. They are represented by the classes Vertex and Edge. Each of these objects defines their positions in terms of the fractional coordinates along the a, b and c vectors of a unit cell. In addtion, each of these objects defines a set of “fg positiions”.

For edges, there are two fg positions, 0 and 1. 0 is the position of the fg which gets connected to an fg on the first vertex connected by the edge, while 1 is the position of the fg which gets connected to the second vertex connected by the edge. Identification of which fg of a di-functionalized building block sits on which fg position is done in the following way. Check the distance of each fg to the first vertex. The closer one is on position 0, the further one is on position 1.

For vertices there are multiple fg positions. The number of fg positions on a vertex is equal to the number of functional groups the building block placed on the vertex has. The fg positions are labelled from 0 to n where n is one less than the number of functional groups in the building block. Going clockwise around the vertex, starting at the 12 o clock position, the positions are labelled starting at 0. After placing and aligning a building block on a vertex, it is necessary to identify which fg sits on which fg position. Alignment is done by rotating the building block around the z axis so that the distance of one of the fgs and one of the edges is minimized. Because each edge keeps a record of which position it connects, the aligned fg can be assigned to a position. Then the fgs are assigned to the next positions in clockwise order.

To join molecules simply go through all the edges in a topology. Each edge holds the vertices it is connected to and the positions on those vertices it connects. Each edge and vertex defines a dictionary which maps the position to the fg which sits on it. For each edge take the fg at position 0 and the fg position on the vertex which is connceted to it. Use the fg position on the connected vertex to get the id of the fg which is to be connected. The same can be done for the fg at position 1 on the edge.

Periodic bonds are not added to the rdkit molecule, instead they are registered in Periodic.periodic_bonds.

class stk.molecular.topologies.cof.COFLattice(scale_func=<function bb_size>)¶

Bases: stk.molecular.topologies.base.Topology

A base class for periodic topologies.

This class behaves almost exactly like Topology with only minor additions to suit the representation of COF periodic lattices. The del_atoms() method is extended to collect the coordinates of any deleted atoms. This is necessary for positioning terminating atoms on islands generated from the periodic structure by Periodic.island().

scale_func¶

function – A function which takes a MacroMolecule as its only argument returns a number. The number is used to scale the size of the unit cell. See bb_size() for an example.

class stk.molecular.topologies.cof.Edge(v1, v2, joint_positions, bond=[0, 0, 0])¶

Bases: object

Represents a bond in a COF unit cell.

This class is used for positioning and aligning ditopic building blocks in 2D COF topologies.

v1¶

Vertex – The first vertex connected by the edge.

v2¶

:class:Vertex` – The second vertex connected by the edge.

joint_positions¶

tuple of int – Holds 2 numbers. The first is the id of the position on v1 which gets connected by the edge. The second is the id of the position on v2 which gets connected by the edge.

bond¶

list of int: – Indicates if the bond is periodic.

connected¶

class:list of Vertex – The vertices conncetd by the edge.

frac_coord¶

list of :class`float` – The position of the edge in terms of the fractional positions along the a, b and c vectors of a unit cell.

fg_map¶

dict – Maps the id of a position to the fg_id of the fg which sits on it. The positions are 0 and 1 where 0 is the position which is closer to v1 while 1 is the position closer to v2.

calc_coord(cell_params)¶

Calcualtes the position of the edge in a cell.

Parameters:cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
Returns:The position.
Return type:numpy.array
create_fg_map(macro_mol, cell_params)¶

Creates the attribute fg_map.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being built.
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
Returns:

None
Return type:

NoneType
direction(cell_params)¶

The direction vector of the edge.

Parameters:cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
Returns:The direction vector.
Return type:numpy.array
fg_centroid(macro_mol, cell_params)¶

The centroid of the fgs connected to the edge.

So the fgs NOT sitting on the edge itself.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
Returns:

The centroid of the fgs connected to those on the edge.
Return type:

numpy.array
fg_direction(macro_mol, cell_params)¶

Calculates the direction vector between the fgs.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
Returns:

The direction vector.
Return type:

numpy.array
place_mol(macro_mol, cell_params, mol, alignment)¶

Places and aligned a building block along the edge.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being built.
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
  • mol (StructUnit3) – The building block to be placed.
  • alignment (int) – Can be 1 or -1 to align mol either parallel or anti-parallel with the edge.
Returns:

The rdkit instance of the placed mol.
Return type:

rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

class stk.molecular.topologies.cof.LinkerCOFLattice(ditopic_directions=None, multitopic_aligners=None, scale_func=<function linker_cof_scale_func>)¶

Bases: stk.molecular.topologies.cof.COFLattice

For 2D COF topologies which use a linker.

These are topologies which consist of 2 building blocks. One which has two functional groups and one which has 3 or more functional groups.

This class will have to be extended by sublcasses which define the vertices and edges which a particular topology consists of.

vertices¶

list of Vertex – Class attribute added when defining a subclass. Holds the vertices which make up the topology.

edges¶

list of Edge – Class attribute added when defining a subclass. Holds the edges which make up the topology.

ditopic_directions¶

list of int – For each edge in the topology, holds 1 or -1 to indicate if the building block is placed parallel or anti-parallel to the edge.

multitopic_aligners¶

list of int – For each vertex in the topology, holds the value of a fg_id of the multitopic bulding block. This is the functional group which gets aligned at a given edge.

bonded_fgs(macro_mol)¶
place_mols(macro_mol)¶

Places the building blocks on the topology.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType

Places and aligns building blocks in the unit cell.

Notes

This method modifies macro_mol. An rdkit molecule of the unit cell with the building blocks not joined up is placed in the mol attribute.

class stk.molecular.topologies.cof.Vertex(frac_coord)¶

Bases: object

Represents a vertex of a 2D COF topology.

frac_coord¶

tuple of float – The fractional positions along the a, b and c vectors of the vector.

connected¶

list of Edge – The edges connected to this vertex.

fg_map¶

dict – Maps the id of a fg position on the vertex to the fg_id of the functional group sitting on it.

aligned_position()¶

Returns the position of the fg aligned by place_mol().

Returns:The id of a position of on the vertex. The fg which gets aligned during place_mol() sits on this position.
Return type:int
calc_coord(cell_params, cell_position=[0, 0, 0])¶

Calculate the position of the vertex within a unit cell.

Parameters:
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
  • cell_position (list of int) – Indicates if the vertex is in a periodic cell or not. Analogous to the defintion of a periodic bond.
Returns:

The position.
Return type:

numpy.array
create_fg_map(macro_mol, cell_params, nfgs, aligned_fg)¶

Creates the attribute fg_map.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being built.
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
  • nfgs (int) – The number of functional groups the building block placed on the vertex has.
  • aligned_fg (int) – The fg_id of a functional group. This is the fg which gets aligned with an edge. The fg_id corresponods to the value in the building block.
Returns:

None
Return type:

NoneType
place_mol(cell_params, mol, aligner)¶

Places and aligns a molecule on the vertex.

Parameters:
  • cell_params (list of numpy.array) – The a, b and c vectors of the unit cell.
  • mol (StructUnit3) – The building block to be placed.
  • aligner (int) – The fg_id of a functional group. This is the fg which gets aligned with an edge.
Returns:

The rdkit instance of the placed mol.
Return type:

rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol
stk.molecular.topologies.cof.bb_size(macro_mol)¶

Sums the diameters of the building blocks.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
Returns:The sum of the diameters of the building blocks. Used to scale the size of unit cells.
Return type:float
stk.molecular.topologies.cof.linker_cof_scale_func(macro_mol)¶

Calculates the scale factor for LinkerCOFLattice.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
Returns:A product of the sum of the diameters of the building blocks and the number of vertices in the unit cell.
Return type:float
